text: I was here because I was starving myself
so I ended up on the eating disorders
unit well initially it was a way of
filling time because I was stuck on a
ward I couldn't get out but I worked on
this same image the same face and it
communicated from my point of view my
own sense of darkness inside and also
the confusion and sometimes aggression I
felt at the treatment that I was
receiving it's very liberating I think
you know so much of hospital life is
prescribed and what art does it is gift
on the free rein just to go in to
themselves and say well this is
basically what it's like for me and this
is what's going on for me and I think
that's incredibly therapeutic
I've seen some amazing art created by
fellow patients many of whom have gone
on to exhibit
the collection here is really
significant we have works of art by
people who were patients at Bethlem and
the Maudsley hospital and elsewhere but
some of those patients are also
internationally renowned artists like
Richard Dada
we also have works that are of real
historic value as well so people who
come to the museum will see zippers
statues of Raving a melancholy madness
which for many many years were major
London landmarks the Bethlem is believed
to be the oldest psychiatric institution
in the world the collections that we've
got here go back to the 1500s so it is
some of the earliest art work and also
objects and archives connected with the
history of mental healthcare probably in
the world safe to say
we'd like people to come here whether or
not they have an interest in mental
health and well-being we'd like people
to come just to enjoy the art but what
we also hope is that people will go away
having thought about some of those
issues and hopefully having a really
good argument with each other about
about some of the issues that we raise
because none of it is entirely
straightforward
it played an enormous role in my
recovery and it's played an enormous
role in my ongoing recovery it's all
been an incredibly positive experience
and it's nice after all the hell to
leave hospital with something that you
can be proud of
you need to see what it's possible for
people who are so often marginalized to
produce artistically you know mental
health needs as much promotion as
possible I think if the 20th century was
the century of the body I think that
21st century will be the century of the
mind and I think we ought the more we
can understand that through our creative
practices the better
